data.title: Best hotels in Newcastle upon Tyne
data.meta_description: Find the best places to stay in Newcastle upon Tyne from the list below, which has been curated based on location, style, rooms, facilities and dining options. Browse hotels in Newcastle upon Tyne and book.
data.text:
8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

This large, modern hotel on Newcastle’s Quayside leads the way in how to blend corporate with leisure: smart facilities and cool design imbue everything with an upbeat vibe. Expect airy, minimalist rooms, floor-to-ceiling windows and a lively restaurant. Read expert review

From

£ 91

pn

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

A grand city mansion that persuades you it’s a rather lovely country house. The Grade ll-listed Arts and Crafts building sits in a pool of green overlooking a wooded valley, yet is only a 10-minute drive from the city centre. Read expert review

From

£ 100

pn

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

The former County Hall for Northumberland, The Vermont is an impressive neo-classical building with a near-perfect location: next to the Castle Keep, with cracking river views and minutes from bars, shops and Quayside. On-site venues include a late-night bar and a clubby restaurant, among others. Read expert review

From

£ 215

pn

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

This is classic Hotel du Vin style – former commercial building, clubby interiors, comfortable but fuss-free bedrooms, terrific bathrooms, French-bistro menu and interesting wines. Though it is close to the Quayside, it's not in the centre of things, so you need to enjoy walking. Read expert review

From

£ 134

per person

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

The Cumberland Arms is a real-ale community pub in a stout Victorian building, situated in Newcastle’s coolest district. Bedrooms are large and comfortable with a simple vintage styling, while the pub downstairs buzzes with music and arty events. Read expert review

From

£ 85

pn

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

A boutique townhouse hotel in a smart Newcastle suburb, close to shops and restaurants, and 10 minutes’ drive from the city centre. It offers good, home-made food and a warm, relaxed atmosphere. Read expert review

From

£ 90

pn

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

A budget hotel with a designer feel sounds like a stretch, but this German-owned brand (Newcastle is its fifth outpost in the UK) pulls it off. With a cool colours, classy materials and clever use of space, it’s smart, relaxed and slap-bang in the centre of the city. Read expert review

From

£ 124

pn

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

A boutique, 148-room, chain hotel sounds like an unlikely top choice, but Hotel Indigo makes a pretty good attempt with its bold colours, over-sized photographs and relaxed atmosphere. It mainly attracts business travellers in the week, and leisure guests who come for its central location at weekends. Read expert review

From

£ 89

pn

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

This modern hotel puts some pizzazz into the usual corporate four-star with its specialty gin bar, decent spa, funky design elements and gritty city views. It’s a big splash of glass in the Stephenson Quarter, the area behind the city's main station, where extensive regeneration is still under way. Read expert review

From

£ 85

pn

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

Next door to the sleek and curvy cultural hub of The Glasshouse, and with genuinely swoon-worthy views of the Tyne Bridge, this mammoth Hilton wins on location but also has a charm that belies its retail-outlet-bland exterior. Read expert review

From

£ 165

pn

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

A cheap and cheery, brightly coloured hostel with predominantly dorm accommodation plus shared bathrooms. There’s a decent kitchen, a pool table and plenty of space for relaxing. It boasts a great location near the station too. Read expert review

From

£ 32

pn

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

This well-priced, contemporary-style hotel is outside the city centre, in one of the buzzier suburbs. Bedrooms are frills-free yet funky while its restaurant has some of the Newcastle's best Thai cuisine. Read expert review

From

£ 105

per person

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

A neat boutique hotel, in a converted Georgian building in an enviable position on the city's premier street. Rooms are smart and uncluttered plus there's a boutique-size beauty treatment retreat offering an assortment of Elemis facials, massages and body scrubs. Read expert review

From

£ 68

pn

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

A budget hotel with style sounds an oxymoron, but Sleeperz hits the spot. Plus it’s in a good central location, which might not be the glitziest part of town but does conveniently back onto the station. The hotel attracts an engaging cross-section, from weekenders to business folk; families to foreign tourists. Read expert review

From

£ 67

pn

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

A good-value and well-located city-centre hotel with modern, frills-free yet thoughtfully designed rooms for both business- and leisure-guests. It serves up generous breakfasts and the staff are on the ball. Read expert review

From

£ 79

pn

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

A large, modern airport hotel, designed for both business and leisure travellers and well-located opposite the terminal. It offers spacious rooms, a buzzy restaurant and bar, plus 24-hour room service. Read expert review

From

£ 136

pn

7 /10 Telegraph expert rating

A family- and business-friendly, mid-range, branded hotel, close to the A1 and airport, with a small, popular leisure centre. Expect Seventies architecture but large, upgraded rooms and a very friendly team. Read expert review

From

£ 132

pn

7 /10 Telegraph expert rating

An upmarket hostel with a bright, fun vibe that is also good value. There’s a large bar and cheap food and, although it’s tucked away in a bit of a no-man's land, the establishment is still central. Read expert review

From

£ 303

pn

7 /10 Telegraph expert rating

In an impressive location overlooking the River Tyne on Newcastle’s buzzy Quayside. In keeping with the Malmaison group, the atmosphere is sultry and romantic; low lighting and dark décor throughout. Find also: a sizeable cocktail bar, decent brasserie, and underground spa. Read expert review

From

£ 130

pn
